articles.headline: California Lawmakers Pass Nation’s Toughest Net Neutrality Law
articles.snippet: The bill is sure to set up a fight between broadband providers, like Verizon and AT&T, and consumer groups.
articles.abstract: The bill is sure to set up a fight between broadband providers, like Verizon and AT&T, and consumer groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — California lawmakers on Friday passed a bill that would guarantee full and equal access to the internet — a principle known as net neutrality — in the biggest pushback yet to the federal government’s rollback of rules last year.

articles.headline: Ayanna Pressley Seeks Her Political Moment in a Changing Boston
articles.snippet: Massachusetts is well known for deeply entrenched politics that favor incumbents. But the Boston City Council member is campaigning for Congress in a moment that has favored women and underdogs.
articles.abstract: Massachusetts is well known for deeply entrenched politics that favor incumbents. But the Boston City Council member is campaigning for Congress in a moment that has favored women and underdogs.
articles.lead_paragraph: • Updated Sept. 4: Ayanna Pressley beat Michael Capuano in the primary on Tuesday night.
articles.byline: By Katharine Q. Seelye and Astead W. Herndon

articles.headline: For Families Split at Border, an Anguished Wait for Children’s Return
articles.snippet: Hundreds of migrant parents were deported from the United States without their children. Back at home, many wonder when, or even if, they will see them again.
articles.abstract: Hundreds of migrant parents were deported from the United States without their children. Back at home, many wonder when, or even if, they will see them again.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN PEDRO SOLOMA, Guatemala — Pablo Domingo isn’t getting much sleep these days. He barely eats and can’t focus on work.
articles.byline: By Kirk Semple and Miriam Jordan

articles.headline: In McCain Memorial Service, Two Presidents Offer Tribute, and a Contrast to Trump
articles.snippet: Barack Obama and George W. Bush were among the political figures from both parties who came to mourn not just a giant of the Senate, but also an ideal that he represented.
articles.abstract: Barack Obama and George W. Bush were among the political figures from both parties who came to mourn not just a giant of the Senate, but also an ideal that he represented.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — He drove them crazy. He berated them on the way to the White House and badgered them once they got there. He stood by them when he thought they were right and tore at their heels when he was convinced they were wrong. And when it came time to depart this world, John McCain wanted them to tell his story.

articles.headline: Agents Tried to Flip Russian Oligarchs. The Fallout Spread to Trump.
articles.snippet: American officials hoped they could persuade some of Russia’s wealthiest men to help with U.S. investigations. It didn’t work.
articles.abstract: American officials hoped they could persuade some of Russia’s wealthiest men to help with U.S. investigations. It didn’t work.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — In the estimation of American officials, Oleg V. Deripaska, a Russian oligarch with close ties to the Kremlin, has faced credible accusations of extortion, bribery and even murder.
articles.byline: By Kenneth P. Vogel and Matthew Rosenberg

articles.headline: If Cardinal Was Under Pope’s Sanctions, Why Was He Allowed at Gala Events?
articles.snippet: A review of Cardinal Theodore McCarrick’s activities during the time he was supposedly under restrictions raises questions of how tough the Vatican is on bishops accused of sexual abuse.
articles.abstract: A review of Cardinal Theodore McCarrick’s activities during the time he was supposedly under restrictions raises questions of how tough the Vatican is on bishops accused of sexual abuse.
articles.lead_paragraph: At a gala dinner in the luxury Pierre Hotel in Manhattan in 2012, Archbishop Carlo Maria Viganò, Pope Benedict’s top diplomat in the United States, bestowed an award for missionary service on Cardinal Theodore McCarrick and praised him as “very much loved from us all.”
articles.byline: By Laurie Goodstein and Jason Horowitz

articles.headline: How Brett Kavanaugh Would Transform the Supreme Court
articles.snippet: Most confirmation hearings concern nominees who would not change the court’s basic direction. Judge Kavanaugh is the rare nominee who would, for two important reasons.
articles.abstract: Most confirmation hearings concern nominees who would not change the court’s basic direction. Judge Kavanaugh is the rare nominee who would, for two important reasons.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Most Supreme Court appointments are in a way inconsequential. A conservative replaces a conservative, a liberal replaces a liberal, and the court’s basic direction is unchanged.

articles.headline: Federal Workers Brace for New Push on Trump Anti-Labor Goals
articles.snippet: President Trump met a legal setback in moving to curb civil servants’ unions, but agencies may be able to achieve the same goals on their own.
articles.abstract: President Trump met a legal setback in moving to curb civil servants’ unions, but agencies may be able to achieve the same goals on their own.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration seemed to suffer a major setback recently when a judge rebuffed its efforts to impose tighter labor rules in federal agencies.

articles.headline: A Swastika on a Church Bell: A Village Splits on How to Confront Nazi Past
articles.snippet: Germany’s painful history has become highly personal in a sleepy village, where neighbors are fighting over what to do with a “Hitler bell” in the local church.
articles.abstract: Germany’s painful history has become highly personal in a sleepy village, where neighbors are fighting over what to do with a “Hitler bell” in the local church.
articles.lead_paragraph: HERXHEIM AM BERG, Germany — After she found out there was a swastika on the church bell, Sigrid Peters refused to continue playing the organ during services.

articles.headline: Meghan McCain’s Eulogy Shows She Is Forged in Her Father’s Image
articles.snippet: Ms. McCain’s emotional call to arms at her father’s funeral was proof that she is her father’s daughter, a paradoxical figure willing to pay the price of being direct.
articles.abstract: Ms. McCain’s emotional call to arms at her father’s funeral was proof that she is her father’s daughter, a paradoxical figure willing to pay the price of being direct.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — As Meghan McCain delivered a eulogy for her father on Saturday, she was at times too grief-stricken to catch her breath. As she described his sickness from brain cancer or his love for her, she struggled to look up at a crowd full of boldface Washington establishment figures who had gathered at National Cathedral.

articles.headline: Companies Say Trump Is Hurting Business by Limiting Legal Immigration
articles.snippet: The government is making it harder to hire foreigners by denying visas, asking for more information and delaying approvals, corporate leaders say.
articles.abstract: The government is making it harder to hire foreigners by denying visas, asking for more information and delaying approvals, corporate leaders say.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Trump administration is using the country’s vast and nearly opaque immigration bureaucracy to constrict the flow of foreign workers into the United States by throwing up new roadblocks to limit legal arrivals.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Steve Lohr

articles.headline: Tech Giants Now Share Details on Political Ads. What Does That Mean For You?
articles.snippet: We tried out new tools from Facebook, Google and Twitter that let you look up campaign ads. Here’s what the databases can — and cannot — do.
articles.abstract: We tried out new tools from Facebook, Google and Twitter that let you look up campaign ads. Here’s what the databases can — and cannot — do.
articles.lead_paragraph: “Dark ads.” That is the catchall term researchers use to describe online political messages that keep people in the dark about why they were targeted with the ads, who paid for them or how much was spent.

articles.headline: Silicon Valley Doesn’t Like Trump. It Can Still Work With the Government.
articles.snippet: Tech workers are pushing back against federal contracts, particularly with the Pentagon. Here’s why that might be a mistake.
articles.abstract: Tech workers are pushing back against federal contracts, particularly with the Pentagon. Here’s why that might be a mistake.
articles.lead_paragraph: Alex Karp grew up in a liberal household and considers himself a progressive. He voted for Hillary Clinton, and he lives and works in Silicon Valley.
